title: The Inflationary Scissors: Rural Hospitals in Crisis
summary: With medical inflation hitting 8% while reimbursement rates remain flat, Vermont's rural hospitals face a mathematical impossibility. This analysis quantifies the purchasing power loss and the resulting erosion of operating margins.

children.text: Rural healthcare is currently caught in a 'Scissors Effect' where the cost of doing business is decoupling from revenue capacity. As inputs (labor, drugs, supplies) rise with the 8% inflation rate, the fixed nature of government reimbursement creates an immediate liquidity crisis.
For the first time in a decade, the cost of delivering care is growing faster than the ability to bill for it. This is not a volume issue; it is a unit price failure.
Inflation is a tax on solvency. When your largest payer (Medicare) offers a 0% real-term update in an 8% inflation environment, you are effectively running a deficit on every patient treated.
